Polymer: Large molecules of repeating units, like in plastics or DNA
Freon: Trade name for refrigerant gases; damaging to the ozone layer
Diffusion: Process by which particles spread out from high concentration to low concentration
Isotope: Atoms of same element with different neutron numbers; used in radiology or carbon dating
Radical: Highly reactive molecule or atom with an unpaired electron
Precipitate: A solid that forms and separates from a liquid during a chemical reaction; often seen in cloudiness or as solids in test tubes
Alloy: Mixture of metals and/or non-metals to create materials with improved properties

Plasma: Ionized, high-energy state of matter with free electrons
Cracking: Breaking large hydrocarbons into smaller ones (e.g., in fuel refining)
Pauling: Pioneer in quantum chemistry and molecular biology; explained nature of chemical bonding, won Chemistry and Peace Nobel Prizes
Catalyst: Speeds up a chemical reaction without being consumed, crucial in oil refining
Sublimation: Transition from a solid to a gas without becoming a liquid, like dry ice into vapor
Mendeleev: Created the first widely accepted periodic table by organizing elements by atomic mass, predicted new elements
Electrolysis: Using electricity to split compounds into elements or simpler compounds
